column4: ok, really silly question here.  on a pc i don't know, and want to install 3d graphcs drivers - how do i find out what gfx card is installed?
try 'lspci'
thats the one!
could you tell me please then? I don't know of the security implications.
$PWD in the path can be used by an attacker to trick you into running an executable you didn't intend to run.
they could plant a malicious program by the name of 'ls' in /tmp for example.
if you happen to do a 'cd /tmp ; ls' you will run a program that you didn't intend to.
'sudo update-grub'
why update twice? And last time I checked, dist-upgrade implied upgrade

update twice was a typo due to not paying attention. I also think that dist-upgrade implies upgrade, but I know that it's safe to do it in two steps and haven't tried doing it in one.  Didn't want to risk someone elses machine.
it won't be. It's possible that it will be backported from gutsy, though
hmm, ok, thanks. Is there a way to tell if/when it will be ready though?
other than by checking dpkg -l mozilla-thunderbird* regularly? I don't think so.
you want /var/lib on a USB drive?
kinda yes
okay, your call. fstab is the way to go. You don't need the UUID, you can use /dev/sdXx in its place to address the partition.
yes, /dev/sdXx would work - but wouldn't that be affected by me sometimes having other drives plugged in etc?
you mean you would sometimes boot with /var/lib/ on the external drive and other times without?
security-relevant fixes go into the regular repositories. Feature updates may be available through backports and proposed

yes, but for example, there is an apache 2.2.9 which includes security fixes etc, and ubuntu only has 2.2.8 at the moment in hardy (including backports) so how can I tell if the security fixes therein have been included?
there are changelogs in /usr/share/doc/packagename/
